Award.AwardTitle: Enabling Probe Based Nanointerrogation: A systems and controls approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The goal of this proposal is to establish a paradigm for real-time determination of material properties for soft-matter using micro-cantilever probes with sharp tips using atomic force microscopes. The successful completion of the project will result in plug and play modules compatible with existing atomic force microscopes which will provide material science researchers with a new real-time tool to image material properties and will enable access to new temporal regimes of investigation.

Intellectual Merit: The main thrust of the enabling concept proposed is to utilize an existing and prevalent mode of imaging topography of soft-matter, and modifying this method to yield information on stiffness and dissipation at the nano-scale. Tools from controls and systems area based on averaging theory and real-time adaptive estimation methods provide a means to realize proposed objectives. The same tools will be employed to discern and utilize higher modes of the cantilever flexure and for novel means of exciting the probing mechanism.

Broader Impacts: The methods proposed are enabling technologies and will open doors for investigating basic science issues by providing high bandwidth determination of material properties. Under proposal goals a prototype of the plug and play module will be made available to the CharFac facility at University of Minnesota, Twin Cities, which is used by diverse set of industry as well as academic researchers. Integration of the nano-interrogation material into the undergraduate control course will aid in incorporation of exciting novel applications of control methods into the curriculum. Instructional modules to be made available to the CharFac user base will enable dissemination of the new systems perspectives to the physics community. The polymer systems to be studied will have direct impact on biological applications.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major outcomes of the project include a method for determining elastic and dissipative properties of material at the nanoscale. The method developed is minimally invasive and thus can be used for soft material such as polymers and biological material. Moreover, the method is implemented in a self-contained module which can be easily integrated into existing imaging instruments. The method is accompanied by analysis of complex dynamics that underlies the imaging method. The project has also resulted in determining mechanical characteristics of important biological molecules, where, proteins with pico-Newton force resolution were folded and unfolded. Another important study undertaken by the project is the use of lasers for studying biological motors, that form the vehicles for transporting material inside cells. The study has yielded significant insights into intracellular transport mechanisms. The methodology developed in this work circumvents the limitations of existing state-of-the-art with the use of experimentally determined models for various components of the optical instrument employed, thus making it possible to probe biological motors at higher speeds. This paradigm also allows significant enhancement in the resolution with which the stepping motion of the motors can be measured.  The broader impact of the project include outreach to the instrumentation industry. Here, the project has recently evaluated the material property determination method for industry adoption and has made outreach efforts to the characterization facility at the University of Minnesota. It has led to two PhD theses and one Masters thesis from a female student.


Last Modified: 01/08/2017
Modified by: Murti Salapaka

Another important study undertaken by the project is the use of lasers for studying biological motors, that form the vehicles for transporting material inside cells.
